elements.content: Tenebrathin (1), a new C-5-substituted γ-pyrone with a nitroaryl side chain, was isolated from the rare actinomycete Streptoalloteichus tenebrarius NBRC 16177. The chemical structure of 1 was elucidated by a spectroscopic analysis using the crystalline sponge method of crystallization-free X-ray crystallography. The biosynthetic origin of the unusual C-5-substituted γ-pyrone in 1 was revealed by a 13C-labeling experiment. Compound 1 exhibited moderate cytotoxicity against several cancer cell lines and likely targets some protein kinases.
elements.clean_text: Tenebrathin (1), a new C-5-substituted γ-pyrone with a nitroaryl side chain, was isolated from the rare actinomycete Streptoalloteichus tenebrarius NBRC 16177. The chemical structure of 1 was elucidated by a spectroscopic analysis using the crystalline sponge method of crystallization-free X-ray crystallography. The biosynthetic origin of the unusual C-5-substituted γ-pyrone in 1 was revealed by a 13C-labeling experiment. Compound 1 exhibited moderate cytotoxicity against several cancer cell lines and likely targets some protein kinases.

elements.content: In the long history of drug discovery, actinobacteria have played an important role as producers of antibiotics. In particular, the genus Streptomyces has significant potential to produce various bioactive secondary metabolites. In contrast, the number of secondary metabolites discovered from non-Streptomyces actinomycetes (often referred as rare actinomycetes) has only gradually increased since the end of the 1970s. However, some secondary metabolites derived from rare actinomycetes also display attractive bioactivities. Intriguingly, recent genome-sequencing projects have revealed that not only Streptomyces but also some rare actinomycetes harbor approximately 20–40 secondary metabolite–biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs).
elements.clean_text: In the long history of drug discovery, actinobacteria have played an important role as producers of antibiotics. In particular, the genus Streptomyces has significant potential to produce various bioactive secondary metabolites. In contrast, the number of secondary metabolites discovered from non-Streptomyces actinomycetes (often referred as rare actinomycetes) has only gradually increased since the end of the 1970s. However, some secondary metabolites derived from rare actinomycetes also display attractive bioactivities. Intriguingly, recent genome-sequencing projects have revealed that not only Streptomyces but also some rare actinomycetes harbor approximately 20-40 secondary metabolite-biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs).

elements.content: Streptoalloteichus tenebrarius NBRC 16177 was originally reported as “Streptomyces tenebrarius” in 1967 by Higgins and Kastner but was reclassified into the genus Streptoalloteichus in 2008 by Tamura et al. S. tenebrarius reportedly produces several aminoglycoside antibiotics (e.g., tobramycin and apramycin) and is regarded as an industrially important microorganism. Interestingly, our antiSMASH analysis revealed that the S. tenebrarius genome comprises approximately 30 secondary metabolite-BGCs, besides the known aminoglycoside-BGCs (Table S1). However, there have been no reports on the secondary metabolites produced by S. tenebrarius other than the aminoglycoside antibiotics, and thus, S. tenebrarius was considered to be an unexploited source of novel bioactive secondary metabolites. We exhaustively analyzed the n-butanol extract of S. tenebrarius by LC–MS and found a novel C-5-substituted γ-pyrone with a nitroaryl side chain, named tenebrathin (1, A). In this study, we describe the isolation, structural elucidation, 13C-labeling experiments, and bioactivity evaluation of 1.
elements.clean_text: Streptoalloteichus tenebrarius NBRC 16177 was originally reported as "Streptomyces tenebrarius" in 1967 by Higgins and Kastner but was reclassified into the genus Streptoalloteichus in 2008 by Tamura et al. S. tenebrarius reportedly produces several aminoglycoside antibiotics (e.g., tobramycin and apramycin) and is regarded as an industrially important microorganism. Interestingly, our antiSMASH analysis revealed that the S. tenebrarius genome comprises approximately 30 secondary metabolite-BGCs, besides the known aminoglycoside-BGCs (Table S1). However, there have been no reports on the secondary metabolites produced by S. tenebrarius other than the aminoglycoside antibiotics, and thus, S. tenebrarius was considered to be an unexploited source of novel bioactive secondary metabolites. We exhaustively analyzed the n-butanol extract of S. tenebrarius by LC-MS and found a novel C-5-substituted γ-pyrone with a nitroaryl side chain, named tenebrathin (1, A). In this study, we describe the isolation, structural elucidation, 13C-labeling experiments, and bioactivity evaluation of 1.

elements.content: (A) Chemical structure of tenebrathin (1). (B) Key 2D NMR (COSY and HMBC) correlations of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Chemical structure of tenebrathin (1). (B) Key 2D NMR (COSY and HMBC) correlations of 1.

elements.content: To elucidate the chemical structure of 1, the whole culture broth (A-3M medium, 1.5 L) was directly extracted with 900 mL of n-butanol. The n-butanol extract was partitioned by repeated silica gel chromatography, and 6.9 mg of 1 was finally purified by reversed-phase HPLC as a yellowish oil. The HR-ESI-MS analysis established its molecular formula as C22H25NO6, but the 13C NMR spectrum of 1 displayed only 20 resonances. Consistent with the low number of 13C NMR resonances, the 1H NMR spectrum displayed two signals corresponding to a para-substituted benzene ring (δH 7.40 and 8.18, J = 8.5 Hz). The HMQC and 1D NMR analysis revealed that the 13C NMR resonances comprise two carbonyl/enol carbons (δC 167.3 and 181.1), five quaternary nonprotonated sp2 carbons (δC 122.8, 137.0, 144.2, 146.1, and 157.7), three aromatic or olefinic methines (δC 123.6, 124.1, and 129.5), one enolic methine (δC 88.9), one quaternary sp3 carbon (δC 63.9), one aliphatic methine (δC 65.9), three aliphatic methylenes (δC 24.39. 24.44, and 38.2), and four methyls (δC 15.5, 16.2, 17.0, and 56.1).
elements.clean_text: To elucidate the chemical structure of 1, the whole culture broth (A-3M medium, 1.5 L) was directly extracted with 900 mL of n-butanol. The n-butanol extract was partitioned by repeated silica gel chromatography, and 6.9 mg of 1 was finally purified by reversed-phase HPLC as a yellowish oil. The HR-ESI-MS analysis established its molecular formula as C22H25NO6, but the 13C NMR spectrum of 1 displayed only 20 resonances. Consistent with the low number of 13C NMR resonances, the 1H NMR spectrum displayed two signals corresponding to a para-substituted benzene ring (δH 7.40 and 8.18, J = 8.5 Hz). The HMQC and 1D NMR analysis revealed that the 13C NMR resonances comprise two carbonyl/enol carbons (δC 167.3 and 181.1), five quaternary nonprotonated sp2 carbons (δC 122.8, 137.0, 144.2, 146.1, and 157.7), three aromatic or olefinic methines (δC 123.6, 124.1, and 129.5), one enolic methine (δC 88.9), one quaternary sp3 carbon (δC 63.9), one aliphatic methine (δC 65.9), three aliphatic methylenes (δC 24.39. 24.44, and 38.2), and four methyls (δC 15.5, 16.2, 17.0, and 56.1).

elements.content: As expected from the 1H NMR data, the presence of the para-substituted benzene ring (C-14 to C-18) was supported by the COSY correlation of H-16/H-17, and the HMBC correlations from H-14, H-16, and H-17 (B). The connections of C-10/C-11/C-12 and C-11/C-19 were established by the HMBC correlations from H-10 and H-19, while the connections of C-12/C-13/C-14 and C-13/C-20 were established by the HMBC correlations from H-14 and H-20 (B). Furthermore, the connections among C-8/C-9/C-10 were constructed by the COSY correlations among H-8, H-9, and H-10 (B). In addition, the presence of a 2-methoxy-6-methyl-γ-pyrone unit (O-1, C-2–C-7, and 2-OMe) was inferred from the HMBC correlations derived from H-3, H-7, and 2-OMe (B), along with the previous 13C NMR data of known γ-pyrone derivatives (Figure S1). Finally, the C–C bond between C-5 and C-8 was established by the HMBC correlations between H-8 and C-4, C-5, and C-6 (B). Among the unassigned heteroatoms (one nitrogen and three oxygens), one of the oxygens was likely to form an epoxide ring between C-11 and C-12 based on the chemical shifts of C-11 (δC 63.9) and C-12 (δC 65.9). Finally, to account for the molecular formula and 13C chemical shifts of the benzene ring (C-15–C-18, Figure S1 and Table S2), the remaining heteroatoms should be included in a nitro functional group at C-18.
elements.clean_text: As expected from the 1H NMR data, the presence of the para-substituted benzene ring (C-14 to C-18) was supported by the COSY correlation of H-16/H-17, and the HMBC correlations from H-14, H-16, and H-17 (B). The connections of C-10/C-11/C-12 and C-11/C-19 were established by the HMBC correlations from H-10 and H-19, while the connections of C-12/C-13/C-14 and C-13/C-20 were established by the HMBC correlations from H-14 and H-20 (B). Furthermore, the connections among C-8/C-9/C-10 were constructed by the COSY correlations among H-8, H-9, and H-10 (B). In addition, the presence of a 2-methoxy-6-methyl-γ-pyrone unit (O-1, C-2-C-7, and 2-OMe) was inferred from the HMBC correlations derived from H-3, H-7, and 2-OMe (B), along with the previous 13C NMR data of known γ-pyrone derivatives (Figure S1). Finally, the C-C bond between C-5 and C-8 was established by the HMBC correlations between H-8 and C-4, C-5, and C-6 (B). Among the unassigned heteroatoms (one nitrogen and three oxygens), one of the oxygens was likely to form an epoxide ring between C-11 and C-12 based on the chemical shifts of C-11 (δC 63.9) and C-12 (δC 65.9). Finally, to account for the molecular formula and 13C chemical shifts of the benzene ring (C-15-C-18, Figure S1 and Table S2), the remaining heteroatoms should be included in a nitro functional group at C-18.

elements.content: In order to determine the geometry of the double bond (C-13 and C-14) and the absolute configuration of the epoxide moiety (C-11 and C-12), we attempted the X-ray structural analysis of 1. However, 1 was isolated as an oily substance and, thus, was not suitable for the conventional X-ray structural analysis requiring a single crystal of the target compound. Thus, we employed the crystalline sponge (CS) method, a recently developed technique that does not require a single crystal of a target compound, which is applicable to oily substances. The CS is a crystal with a porous coordination network, which can trap small molecules within its regularly ordered pores. The trapped molecules are aligned with three-dimensional regularity in the CS, and thus, we can determine their structures and absolute configurations by an X-ray diffraction study. When we incubated 1 with the CS [(ZnCl2)3(tpt)2·x(n-hexane)] n [tpt = 2,4,6-tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine], 1 was successfully introduced into the CS and clearly observed by the X-ray crystallographic analysis (A–C, S2, and S3). Consequently, the double-bond geometry (C-13/C-14) was determined to be E, and the absolute configuration of the epoxide moiety was established as 11R/12R based on the Flack parameter [0.074(8)]. Overall, the chemical structure of 1 was fully established as described in A and represents a new nitroaryl-containing γ-pyrone metabolite.
elements.clean_text: In order to determine the geometry of the double bond (C-13 and C-14) and the absolute configuration of the epoxide moiety (C-11 and C-12), we attempted the X-ray structural analysis of 1. However, 1 was isolated as an oily substance and, thus, was not suitable for the conventional X-ray structural analysis requiring a single crystal of the target compound. Thus, we employed the crystalline sponge (CS) method, a recently developed technique that does not require a single crystal of a target compound, which is applicable to oily substances. The CS is a crystal with a porous coordination network, which can trap small molecules within its regularly ordered pores. The trapped molecules are aligned with three-dimensional regularity in the CS, and thus, we can determine their structures and absolute configurations by an X-ray diffraction study. When we incubated 1 with the CS [(ZnCl2)3(tpt)2⋅x(n-hexane)] n  [tpt = 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine], 1 was successfully introduced into the CS and clearly observed by the X-ray crystallographic analysis (A-C, S2, and S3). Consequently, the double-bond geometry (C-13/C-14) was determined to be E, and the absolute configuration of the epoxide moiety was established as 11R/12R based on the Flack parameter [0.074(8)]. Overall, the chemical structure of 1 was fully established as described in A and represents a new nitroaryl-containing γ-pyrone metabolite.

elements.content: (A) Crystal structure of the 1·CS complex. Two molecules of 1 (guests A and B) are present in the asymmetric unit. Solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. Crystal structures and ORTEP drawings with 50% probability of (B) guest A and (C) guest B.
elements.clean_text: 2  (A) Crystal structure of the 1⋅CS complex. Two molecules of 1 (guests A and B) are present in the asymmetric unit. Solvent molecules are omitted for clarity. Crystal structures and ORTEP drawings with 50% probability of (B) guest A and (C) guest B.

elements.content: Nitroaryl-containing metabolites are relatively rare in nature, but several Streptomyces strains produce nitroaryl-containing pyrone polyketides (Figure S4), including aureothin (2) produced by Streptomyces thioluteus (A). The chemical structures of 1 and other known derivatives are similar, but only the nitroaryl side chain in 1 (C-8 to C-18 in A) is connected to the C-5 position of the pyrone unit, while the side chains in the other known derivatives were all connected to the C-6 position of the pyrone rings (red colored in A and S4). Notably, the C-5-substituted polyketide pyrones were rarely discovered, except for a series of C4-alkyl/-acyl substituted pyrone metabolites produced by several fungi (Figure S5A). The formation of the C-6-substituted pyrone was accountable based on the polyketide synthase (PKS)-based pathway involving the terminal lactonization of the enzyme-bound intermediate (B). In contrast, the formation of the unusual C-5-substituted pyrone in tenebrathin could not be explained by the conventional PKS-based pathway, including several rounds of chain extension followed by lactonization (B).
elements.clean_text: Nitroaryl-containing metabolites are relatively rare in nature, but several Streptomyces strains produce nitroaryl-containing pyrone polyketides (Figure S4), including aureothin (2) produced by Streptomyces thioluteus (A). The chemical structures of 1 and other known derivatives are similar, but only the nitroaryl side chain in 1 (C-8 to C-18 in A) is connected to the C-5 position of the pyrone unit, while the side chains in the other known derivatives were all connected to the C-6 position of the pyrone rings (red colored in A and S4). Notably, the C-5-substituted polyketide pyrones were rarely discovered, except for a series of C4-alkyl/-acyl substituted pyrone metabolites produced by several fungi (Figure S5A). The formation of the C-6-substituted pyrone was accountable based on the polyketide synthase (PKS)-based pathway involving the terminal lactonization of the enzyme-bound intermediate (B). In contrast, the formation of the unusual C-5-substituted pyrone in tenebrathin could not be explained by the conventional PKS-based pathway, including several rounds of chain extension followed by lactonization (B).

elements.content: (A) Chemical structure of aureothin (2, nitroaryl side chain is highlighted in red). (B) Formation of the C-6-substituted pyrone derivatives by the PKS-based pathway. The figure illustrates the case of aureothin.
elements.clean_text: 3  (A) Chemical structure of aureothin (2, nitroaryl side chain is highlighted in red). (B) Formation of the C-6-substituted pyrone derivatives by the PKS-based pathway. The figure illustrates the case of aureothin.

elements.content: In order to elucidate the biosynthetic origin of the C-5-substituted pyrone in 1, we fed 13C-labeled acetates ([1-13C] and [1,2-13C2]-acetates) to the S. tenebrarius culture and isolated 13C-labeled 1. In the 13C NMR spectrum of [1-13C]-acetate-labeled 1, high enrichment levels were observed at C-2, C-4, C-6, and C-8 (A, S6, and Table S3). On the other hand, in the 13C NMR spectrum of [1,2-13C2]-acetate-labeled 1, the signals of C-2 to C-9 existed as a split peak due to the directly bonded 13C–13C couplings of C-2/C-3, C-4/C-5, C-6/C-7, and C-8/C-9 (B and S7–S9). Notably, the labeling pattern of 1 was different from that of aureothin (Figure S10) and consistent with those of pyrenocines (Figure S5B). These results suggested that the pyrone unit of 1 (C-2–C-7) is constructed from three acetate units, but the other polyketide chain derived from the nitroaryl starter unit is branched at the C-5 position of the pyrone.

In the 13C NMR spectrum of [1-13C]-acetate-labeled 1, high enrichment levels were observed at C-2, C-4, C-6, and C-8 (A, S6, and Table S3). On the other hand, in the 13C NMR spectrum of [1,2-13C2]-acetate-labeled 1, the signals of C-2 to C-9 existed as a split peak due to the directly bonded 13C-13C couplings of C-2/C-3, C-4/C-5, C-6/C-7, and C-8/C-9 (B and S7-S9). Notably, the labeling pattern of 1 was different from that of aureothin (Figure S10) and consistent with those of pyrenocines (Figure S5B). These results suggested that the pyrone unit of 1 (C-2-C-7) is constructed from three acetate units, but the other polyketide chain derived from the nitroaryl starter unit is branched at the C-5 position of the pyrone.

elements.content: Results of isotope labeling experiments using (A) [1-13C]-acetate and (B) [1, 2-13C2]-acetate.
elements.clean_text: 4  Results of isotope labeling experiments using (A) [1-13C]-acetate and (B) [1, 2-13C2]-acetate.

elements.content: To obtain further information for the tenebrathin biosynthesis, we searched for a tenebrathin BGC from the output of the antiSMASH analysis (Table S1). As a result, we found one candidate BGC consisting of 11 ORFs (tbtA-K in Table S4), displaying significant similarity to the aur (77%, aureothin BGC) and nor (81%, neoaureothin BGC) clusters. The 11 ORFs in the tbt cluster were divided into four type I PKS-related genes (tbtA-C and -J, Figure S10), one transcriptional gene (tbtD), and six accessory biosynthetic genes (tbtE-H and -K). Based on the comparative analysis among the tbt, aur, and nor clusters (Table S4), it is likely that tbtE-H are responsible for the starter unit biosynthesis (CoA thioester of p-nitrobenzoic acid (PNBA)), and tbtI is responsible for the O-methylation of the pyrone moiety. The biosynthetic role of tbtK (putative flavin adenine dinucleotide-dependent oxidoreductase) is unclear, but it is probably required for the epoxide installation since its counterpart was not observed in the aur/nor clusters. Comparing the type I PKS genes encoded in the tbt cluster (tbtABC) with their counterparts in the aur cluster (aurABC), the domain composition of tbtAB was completely identical to that of aurAB (Figure S10). On the other hand, tbtC encodes a single-module PKS consisting of acyl carrier protein (ACP), ketosynthase (KS), malonyl CoA-selective acyltransferase (AT), and inactive ketoreductase (KR) domains, and it was quite different from that of aurC, which encodes a two-module PKS including a methyl malonyl CoA-selective AT domain (Figure S10). Furthermore, a thioesterase (TE) domain is not included in tbtABC, but instead, tbtJ encodes a stand-alone TE domain with no counterparts in the aur cluster (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text: To obtain further information for the tenebrathin biosynthesis, we searched for a tenebrathin BGC from the output of the antiSMASH analysis (Table S1). As a result, we found one candidate BGC consisting of 11 ORFs (tbtA-K in Table S4), displaying significant similarity to the aur (77%, aureothin BGC) and nor (81%, neoaureothin BGC) clusters. The 11 ORFs in the tbt cluster were divided into four type I PKS-related genes (tbtA-C and -J, Figure S10), one transcriptional gene (tbtD), and six accessory biosynthetic genes (tbtE-H and -K). Based on the comparative analysis among the tbt, aur, and nor clusters (Table S4), it is likely that tbtE-H are responsible for the starter unit biosynthesis (CoA thioester of p-nitrobenzoic acid (PNBA)), and tbtI is responsible for the O-methylation of the pyrone moiety. The biosynthetic role of tbtK (putative flavin adenine dinucleotide-dependent oxidoreductase) is unclear, but it is probably required for the epoxide installation since its counterpart was not observed in the aur/nor clusters. Comparing the type I PKS genes encoded in the tbt cluster (tbtABC) with their counterparts in the aur cluster (aurABC), the domain composition of tbtAB was completely identical to that of aurAB (Figure S10). On the other hand, tbtC encodes a single-module PKS consisting of acyl carrier protein (ACP), ketosynthase (KS), malonyl CoA-selective acyltransferase (AT), and inactive ketoreductase (KR) domains, and it was quite different from that of aurC, which encodes a two-module PKS including a methyl malonyl CoA-selective AT domain (Figure S10). Furthermore, a thioesterase (TE) domain is not included in tbtABC, but instead, tbtJ encodes a stand-alone TE domain with no counterparts in the aur cluster (Figure S10).

elements.content: Thus, 1 and 2 are likely to share a common biosynthetic pathway regarding the starter unit biosynthesis and the upstream PKS elongation (TbtAB/AurAB), consistent with the structural similarity of their nitroaryl side chains (Figures S10 and S11). On the other hand, the biosynthetic pathway regarding pyrone ring formation in 1 is likely to be distinct from the conventional C-6-substituted pyrone ring formation in 2 catalyzed by AurC (B). Most likely, the single module in TbtC iteratively accepts three molecules of malonyl-CoA to construct the unusual C-5-substituted pyrone. Alternatively, it is also possible that TbtC initially accepts two molecules of malonyl-CoA to construct hexaketide intermediate, and it is further coupled with one molecule of acetyl-CoA (Figure S11). Since the PKS modules in TbtABC do not include any TE domains, often required for terminus pyrone ring formation, TbtJ (stand-alone TE domain) is also expected to participate in the C-5-substituted pyrone ring formation in 1 (Figure S11).
elements.clean_text: Thus, 1 and 2 are likely to share a common biosynthetic pathway regarding the starter unit biosynthesis and the upstream PKS elongation (TbtAB/AurAB), consistent with the structural similarity of their nitroaryl side chains (Figures S10 and S11). On the other hand, the biosynthetic pathway regarding pyrone ring formation in 1 is likely to be distinct from the conventional C-6-substituted pyrone ring formation in 2 catalyzed by AurC (B). Most likely, the single module in TbtC iteratively accepts three molecules of malonyl-CoA to construct the unusual C-5-substituted pyrone. Alternatively, it is also possible that TbtC initially accepts two molecules of malonyl-CoA to construct hexaketide intermediate, and it is further coupled with one molecule of acetyl-CoA (Figure S11). Since the PKS modules in TbtABC do not include any TE domains, often required for terminus pyrone ring formation, TbtJ (stand-alone TE domain) is also expected to participate in the C-5-substituted pyrone ring formation in 1 (Figure S11).

elements.content: Finally, we evaluated the bioactivities of 1. Since the nitroaryl-containing pyrones are known to exhibit antitumor activity, we initially tested the cytotoxicities of 1 against the MCF7 (breast cancer), A549 (lung cancer), and HeLa (cervical cancer) cell lines using the methyl thiazole tetrazolium (MTT) assay. Consequently, 1 exhibited moderate cytotoxicity against all of the tested cell lines, with IC50 values against MCF7, A549, and HeLa of 7.9, 46.4, and 1.9 μM. Furthermore, in order to investigate the molecular mechanism, we evaluated the inhibitory effects of 1 against 39 human cancer cell lines (JFCR39), and the results suggested that 1 inhibits the functions of several protein kinase families (Figures S12 and S13 and Table S5). We also tested the antimicrobial activities of 1 against two Gram-positive (Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus) and two Gram-negative strains (Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli) bacterial strains, but obvious growth inhibitory activities were not observed up to 100 μM.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we evaluated the bioactivities of 1. Since the nitroaryl-containing pyrones are known to exhibit antitumor activity, we initially tested the cytotoxicities of 1 against the MCF7 (breast cancer), A549 (lung cancer), and HeLa (cervical cancer) cell lines using the methyl thiazole tetrazolium (MTT) assay. Consequently, 1 exhibited moderate cytotoxicity against all of the tested cell lines, with IC50 values against MCF7, A549, and HeLa of 7.9, 46.4, and 1.9 μM. Furthermore, in order to investigate the molecular mechanism, we evaluated the inhibitory effects of 1 against 39 human cancer cell lines (JFCR39), and the results suggested that 1 inhibits the functions of several protein kinase families (Figures S12 and S13 and Table S5). We also tested the antimicrobial activities of 1 against two Gram-positive (Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus) and two Gram-negative strains (Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli) bacterial strains, but obvious growth inhibitory activities were not observed up to 100 μM.

elements.content: In this study, we discovered a new cytotoxic nitroaryl-containing pyrone polyketide, named tenebrathin (1), from the culture broth of the BGC-abundant rare actinomycete Streptoalloteichus tenebrarius NBRC 16177. Unlike aureothin (2) and other related derivatives (A and S4), the nitroaryl side chain of 1 was branched from the unusual C-5 position of the γ-pyrone unit. Some C-5-substituted polyketide pyrones were found as fungal metabolites (Figure S5A,B), but their detailed biosynthetic mechanisms are still unknown. The bioinformatic analysis of the putative tenebrathin BGC (tbt cluster, Table S4) suggested that the downstream PKS module (tbtC and J) is responsible for the C-5-substituted pyrone ring formation (Figure S11). This study provides a clue toward elucidating the unusual biosynthetic pathway of a C-5-substituted pyrone polyketide, and a detailed investigation is now in progress in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text: In this study, we discovered a new cytotoxic nitroaryl-containing pyrone polyketide, named tenebrathin (1), from the culture broth of the BGC-abundant rare actinomycete Streptoalloteichus tenebrarius NBRC 16177. Unlike aureothin (2) and other related derivatives (A and S4), the nitroaryl side chain of 1 was branched from the unusual C-5 position of the γ-pyrone unit. Some C-5-substituted polyketide pyrones were found as fungal metabolites (Figure S5A,B), but their detailed biosynthetic mechanisms are still unknown. The bioinformatic analysis of the putative tenebrathin BGC (tbt cluster, Table S4) suggested that the downstream PKS module (tbtC and J) is responsible for the C-5-substituted pyrone ring formation (Figure S11). This study provides a clue toward elucidating the unusual biosynthetic pathway of a C-5-substituted pyrone polyketide, and a detailed investigation is now in progress in our laboratory.
